results.title: Cooking kangaroo
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
A Pintubi man prepares and cooks a red kangaroo and divides it among his family. (Some scenes may offend animal rights supporters).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: At Patantja clay pan
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Daily activities of two families camped near a clay pan holding water, showing desert food resources in a good season. The men hunt emus and the women collect mulga seed, ngaru fruit and grubs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Two laws. Part 2: Welfare times
results.creator_credit: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Part 2 of the docudrama “Two laws”. Describes the life of the Borroloola community under the welfare system of the 1950s to the present day. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Gum preparation, stone flaking etc; (Episode 2)
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: In 1965 and in 1967 the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies sponsored a film trip, but eh Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, to the Western Desert Region of Australia. The object of the trip was to film the daily life of nomadic Aborigines of the area. An attempt was made to locate groups still living in the desert. 63,000 feet of film were shot and in this record, or archival version of the material, every shot having ethnographic value is included. Film grammar has, in every case, taken second place. The film is divided into nineteen parts, seventeen of which were purchased for inclusion in the Film Library. Parts 3 and 11 were not purchased as they contain sacred material and , as such, are not suitable for use in schools. The seventeen parts which are in the library are more suited for used in secondary schools than in primary schools. However, titles will be recommended by Curriculum and Research Branch for use with the new Primary Social Studies Course. For general screenings, a condensed version has been made under the title of “Desert People”, catalogue number 2790. 3604. Part 1, 21 min, b&w. Seed-cake making and general camp activity. 3602. part 2, 19 min b&w. Gum preparation, stone flaking, Djagamara leave Badjar.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 005
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This cinemagazine features the following items: swimming instruction classes in New South Wales; problems with traffic in Melbourne; Aborigines show their skill with the stockwhip; Sulman architectural awards and strange animals at the Melbourne Zoo.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 003
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The following items are featured in this interesting cinemagazine: a look at a Brisbane creche; Spanish monks and nuns teach Aboriginal children at New Norcia, a mission in Western Australia; families shown mining mica at Harts Range in the Northern terrotory and a Victorian fashion parade as models exhibit the latest styles in woollen clothing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Art of the hunter
results.brief_description: Shows Aborigines making weapons, hunting, cooking and painting on bark. Also shows some rare cave paintings. Filmed in the Northern Territory near Darwin.

results.title: Women of the sun: 25 years later
results.creator_credit: Bob Weis, Julie Andrews and Generation Films
results.brief_description: The impact of the landmark 1981 Australian television drama series “Women of the Sun” on its audience was profound. Groundbreaking in its attempts to present stories of Aboriginal Australian women from their own perspectives and in their own languages, the series won the United Nations Media Peace Prize. In this moving documentary, Bob Weis - the producer of the series - explores the effects “Women of the Sun” has had on the lives of some of those involved with its making. Weis interviews some of the people who acted in the series - Justine Saunders, Shirley Nirrpurrangyydji, Naykalan Mununggur, Michelle LaCombe and Eva Johnson - as well as series co-writer Sonia Borg, and indigenous academic Marcia Langton. The film also features remarkable archival footage of series co-writer, poet and educator Hyllus Maris.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bob Weis, Julie Andrews and Generation Films

results.title: Knot at home project: disc two
results.creator_credit: Phillip Crawford, BIG hART, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: The eight films included in the two Knot at Home titles are the result of a series of community projects run by BIG hART, a non profit community organisation. The projects were designed to give people who often go unheard a chance to tell their stories. From 1998 to 2004 over five hundred young people were asked to tell stories about when they felt “not at home”. The “Knot at Home” films present their stories using interviews, narratives, vignettes, songs, animations, dramatised scenes and memories. The young storytellers have made the films themselves, mentored by experienced filmmakers. Contents of “Knot at Home Disc Two” are: Program Five, “Stories of my Family”; Program Six, “Stories of Loyalty” (short film sequences directed by Nathan Brown and Phillip Crawford); Program Seven, “Stories of Insight”; and Program Eight, “Stories About Telling my Story” (short film sequences directed by Rachel Ward). Disc One [319750].
